title: 105_hr4198
content: The "Child Support Security Act" ensures that individuals and states retain the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is maintained. Additionally, unpaid child support payments may be included in income. The "Child Support Security Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include unpaid child support payments as taxable income for the taxpayer. This ensures that child support payments are maintained and included in gross income. The "Child Support Security Act" requires eligible taxpayers to send a notice to individuals who failed to make child support payments, informing them to include the amount in their gross income. The "Child Support Security Act" mandates eligible taxpayers to notify non-paying individuals to include the owed amount in their gross income for the previous taxable year. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send the notice if the address is available. If no address is known, no income needs to be included for any taxable year before the year preceding the potential notice. The "Child Support Security Act" requires non-paying individuals to include owed child support payments in their gross income. Subsequent payments can be deducted in the year they are made. Definitions for "applicable child support payments" and "eligible taxpayer" are provided in section 166(f). These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Amends Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments remaining at the end of the taxable year for eligible taxpayers. The maximum deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers is $5,000. An eligible taxpayer is defined as an individual with an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000, unpaid child support payments of $500 or more, and meeting identification requirements. The term "applicable child support payment" refers to the unpaid child support amount for the taxable year. The tax deduction for eligible taxpayers includes periodic fixed payments or payments for medical, educational expenses, insurance premiums, or similar items required by a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. A qualifying child is defined as a child for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151 for the taxable year. The tax deduction for eligible taxpayers includes periodic fixed payments or payments for medical, educational expenses, insurance premiums, or similar items required by a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child. Payments must be delinquent for at least an entire year and not treated as unpaid child support if at least half of the payments required are made during the 12-month period. Coordination with AFDC is also considered. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes payments assigned to a State under the Social Security Act. Identification requirements for claiming the deduction include providing the child's information and the individual responsible for making the payments. In case of failure to provide information, the eligible taxpayer can certify that the information is not known. Cost-of-living adjustments increase certain dollar amounts for taxable years after 1998. Subsequent payments where a deduction was allowed will be included in the eligible taxpayer's gross income for the year in which they are paid. This does not apply if the right to receive the payment has been assigned to a State. A support instrument includes divorce decrees, separation agreements, or court decrees related to parental support. The amendment requires parents to make child support payments, allows deduction for unpaid child support payments, and includes child support payments as applicable debts. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 1997. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will only be used to pay off US public debt, as specified in appropriation Acts, and cannot be used for any other purpose, regardless of other laws not mentioning this section specifically.
